Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Power Reduction for AI Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to advance artificial intelligence computing for a wide range of applications including in data centers and for unmanned autonomous vehicles. According to Forbes, in 2017 U.S. data centers consumed more than 90 Billion Kilowatt hours of energy. Due to Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things, the expectation is that data center energy consumption will have grown by 2X by 2023, or 15% year-over-year increase. On the side of power-constrained machines, such as drones and robots, power consumption for computing is severely limited to milli-Watts of power. The impact to these industries, to enable AI inference computation is the power savings of 80X over traditional electronics.

This I-Corps project develops ultra-low power reconfigurable nano-switches as memory. Artificial Intelligence inference cpmputing has high energy costs due to the large number of multiply-accumulate (MAC) functions required at each node in the neural network, often millions to hundreds of millions of operations for a single inference calculation. These ultra-low power reconfigurable switches store the AI model weights, and replace dynamic ram (DRAM) memory. Simulated results indicate 80X power reduction for each memory read needed for MAC operation. These switches are compatible with complementary metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) technology and can be produced at a minimal cost adder from a standard CMOS process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our I-Corps team Excellerai was comprised of Urmita Sikder (TL), Rebecca Mih (EL), and Edmond Macaluso (IM). Our team was interested in defining the product-market-fit for a novel ultra-low power memory device which will revolutionize artificial intelligence calculation speed at a fraction of the power usage. Over the course of 7 weeks and subsequent months, the team interviewed more than 120 industrial experts as potential customers or competitors in the artificial intelligence computing ecosystem, as well as potential partners and supporters in semiconductor component manufacturing and distribution.

Prior to engaging in the NSF I-Corps program, US (CTO) and RM (CEO) team members had already formulated a start-up company, Excellerai LLC. At the end of the I-Corp program, a rearrangement of roles ensued, with Urmita Sikder planning to transition into an academic role. Rebecca Mih has decided to pursue alternative professional opportunities, and is now employed at Apple.

The learnings and opportunities resulting from this NSF program were invaluable: The ability to cold call or drop in on over 100 customers and stakeholders in the ecosystem, the ability to attract attention in a matter of seconds and compel them to talk about their thoughts and meaningful dialogue, is very different from typical PhD training. RM’s previous bias’ and beliefs had been that this could only be accomplished by seasoned sales people, and was delighted at a new-found skill borne of necessity.

The opportunity and coaching from NSF I-Corps to cast a wide net into markets which may benefit from a broad and fundamental technology is priceless.
